channel.title: Share on Sensr.net Blog | Watch your Stuff!
channel.description: Recent content in Share on Sensr.net Blog | Watch your Stuff!

item.title: The Great Pacific Race on Sensr.net
item.description:
The biggest, baddest human endurance competition on the planet is sharing a camera on sensr.net! The Great Pacific Race is an ocean rowing race from Monterey, California to Honolulu, Hawaii. The competitors have no sails or motors, only their bodies to row them across the biggest ocean in the world! The boats left on June 7th but as they were gearing up and preparing for their journey the Great Pacific Race setup a camera and shared the staging area with the world! You can check out their camera here.

You can see the boats about to be launched here:

Boats lined up

Here they are headed out of the harbor:

Team Canada

For now the feed is down since the boats are still crossing the pacific but hopefully it will be back up once they reach Honolulu!

item.title: Share Your Camera with the Police?
item.description:
[

]1The San Jose police are interested in getting access to security cameras from citizens who volunteer access, according to the San Jose Mercury News. I have a couple driveway cameras that I wouldn’t mind sharing with the police. In fact, I’ve considered making them public cameras. The cameras don’t show anything that you couldn’t see by driving by my house on a public street. Of course having archives is a more powerful thing than simply a live stream.

With Sensr.net cameras are private by default, but you can make your cameras public and anyone can see them. (Here’s a list of all our public cameras.) We also have a guest access feature, where you can give specific users access to the camera. This might be a good option for the SJPD. Users could add guest access to the an account for the police department, allowing them to view the cameras but also keeping the cameras hidden from the public. We’ve had the guest access feature for quite some time.

Maybe it’s time to contact the police!

item.title: Webcam Timelapse from Columbine Lake
item.description: Sensr.net webcams allow you to create clips. I created this clip today when checking the public cameras we have on the site.  This is a particularly peaceful and snowy timelapse.  Winter seems to have arrived at Lake Columbine!

item.title: Guest Access for Sensr.net Cameras
item.description:
Use the INVITE button to manage your guest list

Would you like to share your Sensr.net camera with a few trusted folks?  Now you can.   Want to let Grandma check on the kids in the playroom?  Want to let the dog walker keep an eye on Fido?  Just go to your camera and click the INVITE button and you’ll get a popup window that will let you manage your camera’s guest list.

Here’s an example guest list for my Shelford Knight camera.   It’s a private camera and I’ve invited two users to have guest access.  (I’ve blacked out their email addresses in this screenshot for privacy reasons.)  You can see that they have both accepted the invitation.  If you want to remove someone from the guest list, just click the X next to their email address, and they won’t be able to access your camera anymore.

Manage your camera's guest list

When you invite a guest, we’ll send them an email with the invitation.  If they don’t have a Sensr.net account, they can create one for free.

Guests are allowed to:

  • View any part of your camera
  • Create clips, both private and public
  • Leave comments on your camera

Guests are not allowed to:

  • Delete images from cameras
  • Change camera settings
  • Invite other guests

Let us know what you think!

item.title: Watch and Control Your Christmas Lights Remotely
item.description:
We finally got around to setting up our Christmas tree last night. This morning I realized that I could watch the tree via Sensr.net.  I grabbed a spare camera and pointed it at the tree.

Just for fun, I also connected the lights to a Wayne-Dalton Z-Wave Outdoor Appliance Module.  Since I have a Vera home automation system from Mi Casa Verde, I can now turn the lights on and off remotely while I’m watching!

Of course you can also embed a live view in your web page if you like, see this post on how to embed your camera’s live view into your web page.

Happy Holidays!

Bonus Points:  There are a lot of interesting web connected Christmas light projects out there.  One of the more sophisticated is CheerLights which controls the lights via Twitter.

item.title: More camera info!
item.description:
New user editable camera fields.

You can now add information about your sensr.net camera. Go to the DVR page for your [

Tweet

New user editable camera fields.

You can now add information about your sensr.net camera. Go to the DVR page for your]1 camera and simply click to edit the fields below the camera images.

  • Description
  • Model
  • Homepage
  • Location

    • Why should you add this info?  It will make it easier for folks to find your camera using the sensr.net search field. If you share your camera with your friends, it will also let your friends know more about your camera. If you share your camera with the world, it will let others find your camera more easily.

    For instance, you can search for all the cameras in Incline Village and you’ll get these three cameras.  As more and more folks add camera info, we’ll be able to surface more interesting search results on sensr.net and your camera will get more views!

    Search results for 'Incline Village'

    You’ll need to be logged in before you can edit the camera information for your camera.  And of course, you can’t edit the camera information for other users’ cameras.  We also support comments, if you have something to say about another user’s camera.  But we’ll save that for another blog post.

item.title: Fun video made with sensr.net
item.description:
Here’s a fun video made by one of our sensr.net users, Attila Radnai.  You can find the live camera here. As we’ve mentioned before, you can easily make YouTube videos from your sensr.net camera.  I particularly like the music that Mr. Radnai chose!  This is exactly the kind of creativity we hope to keep inspiring on sensr.net.

Keep rolling!

item.title: Search and Friends: Finding cameras on Sensr.net
item.description:
Even though some of the sensr.net startup DNA comes from Truveo, a video search company, we didn’t implement search at Sensr until today.  As of this morning, there are two new ways to find camera on Sensr.  You can search or you can get a list of any cameras your Facebook friends have setup.

Two new ways to find cameras on sensr.net

Search 1.0

Our first version of search is simple but effective.  You can find cameras based on the camera name or the name of the user who owns the camera.  You’ll get different results depending on whether or not you’re logged into the site.  We filter the cameras based on accessibility.  On Sensr you have the ability to make a camera public, private, or shared with your Facebook friends.  This means if you’re my friend and search for ‘adam’ then you’ll see public cameras I’ve added as well as cameras that I’m only sharing with my friends.

My Friends’ Cameras

We’ve also added  a menu item that allows you to see a list of cameras owned by your friends.  Again, this will show you cameras that your friends have added and to which you have access.  (You won’t be able to see your friend’s private cameras.)    You’ll need to log into the site with your Facebook id before this will work.  After you do that, just hover over your name and a menu will drop down showing the my friends’ cameras option.  Just click on that and you’ll be browsing any shared cameras that your friends have added.

Get Your Own Camera

Need to add a camera to the site?  We support almost all IP cameras.  We’re adding more and more per model instructions to the blog all the time.  Here’s the current list, but it is by no means complete.  Want to know if your camera will work?  Drop us an email and we can let you know if it will work with Sensr.

item.title: Making YouTube Videos from Sensr.net Cameras
item.description:
If you have a camera on Sensr.net, you can easily create a YouTube video to share with the world. Here’s a sample video showing a nice time lapse of the clouds over Toronto.

To create a video like this, simply go to your camera’s page on the Sensr.net site and click on the DVR tab. You’ll end up on a view like the one shown below. You can simply play all the images from the camera on this page to see what’s going to be in the video. If you don’t want to use the entire hour, you can click the TRIM button and trim tabs will appear. You can use those to select the subset of the video that you want to use in your YouTube video.

DVR View

Once you have trimmed the video segment to your liking, you can then click on the YOUTUBE button and upload the video to your YouTube account. You’ll have to authorize the sensr.net site with your YouTube login. After that, we’ll generate a video and upload it to your account. It usually takes a few minutes for our servers (and YouTube’s) to generate the video and get it live. You’ll be able to find the final video under My Videos on the YouTube site.

This allows you to have a private cameras on the sensr.net site, but selectively share portions of that camera with the world.

Give it a try!

item.title: Save everything, Share what you want
item.description:
At Sensr.net we’re building a fun service for monitoring and sharing your IP camera. Today we released a new feature that allows you to tweet images from your private or semi-private cameras while protecting the overall privacy of your camera.

Sensr.net is built around always-on network cameras. We store all the motion events from your cameras, forever. At least for now. (Eventually we may need to charge for storage or put some upper limits on the free accounts.) Think about this. If your camera is archived in the cloud forever, you’re bound to catch some interesting images and videos.

Personally, I have a camera running in the playroom of our house. This means I have a long term archive of my kids’ shenanigans. Do I want to world to have unfettered access to that camera? No way. Do I think this archive is valuable? Absolutely! Do I want to share images from this camera with the world? Sometimes.

So here’s how it works. If you tweet an image from a camera on sensr.net, we’ll create a special page that allows anyone to see that image and only that image. Twitter is by default a public forum. By tweeting an image from a private sensr.net camera you’re giving the world permission to view that single image. We think this is an important step in the right direction.

Here’s what it looks like in action. This is a screen shot of the DVR for my playroom camera. I’ve added a little tweet bubble to show you where you click to tweet an image. (Yes, I’m no graphic designer…)

Sensr.net DVR View

Once you click the tweet button, you’ll get the standard Twitter popup window that will let you edit your tweet. It looks something like this:

Twitter Popup

Your tweet will end up on a special page that only points to the image you’ve shared. The page is a bit bland, but we’ll make it nicer over time. The important thing here is that you’re able to share a subset of your camera’s archive without sharing the entire camera.

Share a single image page.

What if you don’t want to share an image with the world? We also support Facebook photo uploads. In this case you can upload an image to your Facebook Photos. This gives you the ability to share photos with your selected Facebook friends.

Dont’ want to use Twitter or Facebook? You can always download an image and email it to your friends. Just right click on the image and select “Save Image As” to store the image on your hard drive. You can now email it to exactly whomever you want to see it.

Get Started

If you already have an IP camera, chances are it will work with Sensr.net. We’re starting to fill our blog with detailed instructions for various camera models. We’ll keep adding camera models as fast as we can. If you can’t figure out how to add your camera, leave a comment on our blog or click the feedback link on the main Sensr.net site. We’ll help you get started.

If you don’t have an IP camera yet, take a look around our blog or read our FAQ for some suggestions.
